name: Meta AI
Summary: Three interesting new research papers you should know about from Meta AI at #ACL2023NLP — and where you can find more details if you’re not at the conference. Expand, Rerank, and Retrieve: Query Reranking for Open-Domain Question Answering  https://bit.ly/44ER5ZpWe propose EAR, a query Expansion And Reranking approach for improving passage retrieval, with the application to open-domain question answering. EAR first applies a query expansion model to generate a diverse set of queries, and then uses a query reranker to select the ones that could lead to better retrieval results.Meta-learning with Demonstration Retrieval for Efficient Few-shot Learning  https://bit.ly/46EP5lTWe propose meta-training with demonstration retrieval, where we use a dense passage retriever to retrieve semantically similar labeled demonstrations to each example for more varied supervision. By separating external knowledge from model parameters, we can use meta-training to train parameter-efficient models that generalize well on a larger variety of tasks.UnitY: Two-pass Direct Speech-to-speech Translation with Discrete Unit  https://bit.ly/3JQeuPDWe present a novel two-pass direct speech-to-speech translation architecture, which first generates textual representations and predicts discrete acoustic units subsequently. We enhance the model performance by subword prediction in the first-pass decoder, advanced two-pass decoder architecture design and search strategy, and better training regularization.

Building custom silicon, especially for the first time, is a significant undertaking. Summary: Meet MSVP — our first in-house silicon for video processing.More details  https://bit.ly/3o9ARYOAt Meta's scale we need a video encoding solution that can deliver the best video quality possible — with the shortest amount of encoding time — all while being energy efficient, programmable and scalable. This is where handware acceleration thrives. Meta Scalable Video Processor (MSVP) processes videos 9x faster than traditional software encoders and delivers the same video quality at 1/2 of the energy. It allows our infrastructure to improve the overall quality and compression efficiency of our video encoding across every codec we use.MSVP is just the first milestone in our effort to develop new hardware-assisted video processing solutions. In the future, MSVP will allow us to support even more of Meta's most important use cases and needs, including short-form videos, enabling efficient delivery of generative AI content, AR/VR and other metaverse content in the future.

Summary: Do SSL models have a case of Déjà Vu?Read the paper  https://bit.ly/429QwpiIn a new paper, we performed a systematic study of the unintended memorization of image-specific information in SSL models. The work uncovered new, previously unknown risks in SSL models which we refer to as déjà vu memorization. This type of memorization is common to different SSL algorithms, is exacerbated by certain design choices, and cannot be detected by conventional techniques for evaluating representation quality. As part of this work Meta AI researchers suggest new, potential practical mitigation strategies for consideration by others in the field working to build new SSL models.

On top of this, DINOv2 doesn't require fine-tuning — making it suitable as a backbone for many different types of computer vision tasks.Self-supervised computer vision models like DINOv2 will be useful in a wide variety of applications. For example, Meta collaborated with the World Resources Institute to use AI to map forests, tree by tree, across areas the size of continents. Our self-supervised model was trained on data from forests in North America, but evaluations confirm that it generalizes well and delivers accurate maps in other locations around the world.Learn more about this newly released work  https://bit.ly/3oeaOPLTry the demo  https://bit.ly/3L6ke8V

Summary: Segmentation has far-ranging use cases and implications, from creative to geological, scientific and much more. Today we're releasing Segment Anything, an important step toward the first foundation model for image segmentation — and an accompanying dataset to help progress the field.This new model is capable of one-click segmentation and masking any object from any photo or video. While typical segmentation models have been limited to highly specialized and narrow tasks, Segment Anything Model (SAM) has learned a general notion of what objects are and can generate masks for any object in any image, including types that it didn’t see during training.More details  https://bit.ly/3U8FdecTry the demo  https://bit.ly/3KaFFEjIn addition to the new model, we’re releasing a Segment Anything dataset of over 1 billion masks (SA-1B), which is 400x larger than existing segmentation datasets. It was collected using SAM and was also used to train it. Human annotators used the model to interactively annotate images, and this data was used to update the model. We repeated this cycle many times to continuously improve both the model and dataset, ultimately reaching a state where we were able to generate the final version of SA-1B automatically without human feedback.We hope this work will help accelerate computer vision research and enable entirely new applications.

name: Meta AI
Summary: New paper: Learning to Read Braille: Bridging the Tactile Reality Gap with Diffusion Models. Together with researchers at University of Washington, we present Tactile Diffusion, the first method to leverage probabilistic diffusion models for narrowing the sim2real gap for vision-based tactile sensing. Tactile diffusion generates from sim depth data tactile images that realistically render the complex illumination changes due to the gel deformation.On real braille reading tasks with a DIGIT sensor, a classifier trained with our diffusion model outperformed classifiers trained with simulation fine-tuned with 4x more real data.Read the full paper  https://bit.ly/3nKchxc

Summary: Today, we're announcing two major advancements in our work toward general-purpose embodied AI agents that can help form the foundation for embodied intelligence.More details on this new research  https://bit.ly/40vsKUfOptimistic science fiction typically imagines a future where humans create art and pursue fulfilling pastimes while AI-enabled robots handle dull or dangerous tasks. But while we're seeing the use of AI expand quickly in knowledge and creative tasks, robots aren't yet doing our household chores. VC-1 and ASC by Meta AI researchers are taking a step toward robots that can better generalize from human videos & simulated interactions and apply those learnings to real-world tasks.We are optimistic about how these advancements could one day serve as building blocks for AI-powered experiences where virtual assistants and physical robots can assist humans and interact seamlessly with both the virtual and physical world.

Summary: Newly published in Science Magazine today — Meta AI researchers developed a breakthrough model for protein folding by using a large language model that can accelerate folding by up to 60x — with the potential to aid work in medicine, green chemistry, renewable energy & more.Additionally today, using this model and thanks to the latest additions to the MGnify database by European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI), we're excited to share that we’ve expanded the ESM Atlas from 617M predicted protein structures to 740M+ by computationally folding the additional sequences in just 6 days using spare capacity in our GPU cluster. We're excited to share these with the scientific community and can't wait to see what others in the field are able to do with this expanded resource in this ever-important space.

name: Meta AI
Summary: Today we’re open-sourcing Casual Conversations v2.To evaluate fairness rigorously in applications like computer vision and speech recognition, AI researchers need data that shows how well a model works for different demographic groups. We released Casual Conversations in 2021 as the first consent-driven data set that includes self-identified categories of participants having video conversations. With today’s release of Casual Conversations v2, we’re introducing a new dataset to include a broader and more granular list of self-identified and annotated categories, plus the inclusion of recordings from seven countries.With a more diverse data set, researchers can fine-tune AI models even further, with greater opportunities to evaluate fairness when it comes to categories such as language, voice timbre and more. More info on the work that went into this updated dataset in this new post on the Meta AI blog  https://bit.ly/41VFG7a

name: Meta AI
Summary: Speech translation systems can be more robust to background noise in real-world settings if they look as well as listen, like humans do. In a new paper, Meta AI researchers introduce MuAViC, the first open  multilingual audio-visual corpus for robust speech recognition and translation. This dataset makes it possible to use audio-visual learning for highly accurate speech translation.We used MuAViC to train our AV-HuBERT model, using sound + sight, to translate speech in noisy, challenging settings and achieved results that outperformed other leading translation models. We believe that speech translation technology has incredible potential to bring people together and unlock new opportunities. By sharing this work, we’re excited to see how others in the research community will be able to build on this and create translation systems that make an even larger impact in real-world settings.More on our blog  https://bit.ly/3F119Ss

name: Meta AI
Summary: How can robots learn object manipulation for everyday tasks just by watching videos of humans in different unstructured settings? In 'Zero-Shot Robot Manipulation from Passive Human Videos', a new paper by Meta AI researchers working with teams at CMU, we outline our Zero-Shot Human2Robot (H2R) framework.Trained with diverse human videos, our H2R framework learns to predict future action trajectories given a scene, and maps it to the robot’s frame for execution. We evaluate on several coarse manipulation tasks involving several articulated objects, tool-use, and planar motions on a table in both goal-conditioned and unconditioned settings.More details & paper  https://bit.ly/3STAAnU

name: Meta AI
Summary: AI language models have made remarkable progress in generating meaningful texts — Still, data suggests they are still far from the capabilities of the human brain. However we hope that this newly published work in Nature from Meta AI researchers will help to guide the development of the next generation of AI.Read the open accessed article  https://go.nature.com/3YfFOvfMeta AI researchers explore this unexplained gap with predictive coding theory. Summary: Exploration in complex environments is a long-standing problem in reinforcement learning.Although many methods have been proposed, they are primarily designed for environments which do not change, and fail in more realistic settings which require generalization. While recent methods have begun to tackle this more complex setting, they heavily rely on task-specific knowledge which limits their effectiveness. Exploration via Elliptical Episodic Bonuses (E3B) is a new algorithm recently accepted at NeurIPS which uses a simple, scalable and robust exploration bonus designed for changing environments.  E3B sets a new state-of-the-art across 16 challenging tasks from the MiniHack suite, solving the majority of them without requiring task-specific prior knowledge or feature engineering.E3B can also scale to high-dimensional pixel-based observations, surpassing existing methods for reward-free exploration on Habitat, a photorealistic simulator for indoor home navigation. Furthermore, the algorithm is simple and easy for researchers to build on. The research paper and code are now available: https://bit.ly/3DJuXmaThank you to Meta AI Research Scientists Mikael Henaff and Roberta Raileanu, PhD student Minqi Jiang and University College London Associate Professor Tim Rocktäschel for their work on E3B.

Summary: Today, we are sharing how we built an AI system that can interpret Show More and Show Less signals from select posts to predict the types of content people want to see in their Feeds. Likes on posts generate billions of examples that give us a general indication of what people like, but they don’t perfectly capture people’s preferences. Show More/Show Less allows people to directly tell us what they want in their Feeds. Since we have data points that areorders of magnitude less than likes, we have to be more efficient with data. We use embeddings, a language entity transferred into numbers, and train them on behavior to help our model make predictions. By taking an aggregate signal from people, we are able to use AI to improve the Feed experience for everyone. Summary: Existing methods of decoding speech from brain activity have largely focused on invasive approaches, such as implants. Today, we’re sharing new research that could be a significant step forward in a medical setting for decoding brain activity using noninvasive electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG).We trained a contrastive learning model on a large number of noninvasive brain recordings of healthy volunteers listening to audio books. Our results show that we can decode speech with up to 73% top-10 accuracy from a vocabulary of more than 793 words. This is an exciting result because it shows that AI can interpret the noisy signals from noninvasive sources, which could have a greater impact for many use cases, including empowering people with communication deficits.Special thanks to researchers Jean Remi King, Alexandre Défossez, Charlotte Caucheteux, Ori Kabeli, and Jérémy Rapin for their contributions.Learn more on our blog: https://bit.ly/3cz2C7j

Summary: Writing is often a collaborative process: We start with a draft, ask for suggestions & repeatedly make changes. Today we’re introducing PEER, a model trained to mimic this process, enabling it to incrementally write texts and to collaborate with humans in more natural ways.PEER can write drafts, add suggestions, follow instructions, perform edits, correct itself and provide explanations for all its actions. Trained mostly on Wikipedia's edit history, PEER clearly outperforms much larger models on a collection of different editing tasks.We show how infilling techniques improve PEER's ability to write texts in different domains, to follow instructions and to use, cite and quote from provided evidence documents, improving its verifiability, faithfulness and trustworthiness compared to regular large LMs.PEER was developed by Timo Schick, Jane Dwivedi, Zhengbao Jiang, Fabio Petroni, Patrick Lewis, Gautier Izacard, Qingfei You, Christoforos Nalmpantis, Edouard Grave, Sebastian Riedel.Read our paper here: https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11663

Summary: Today we’re introducing Atlas, a new retrieval-augmented lang. model with strong few-shot performance on question answering and fact checking tasks. w/ only 11B parameters, Atlas outperforms a 540B parameter model by 3% w/ 64 training exs., reaching 42% on NaturalQuestions.World knowledge presents a particularly tricky challenge in few-shot NLP, where models don’t just need to understand what the task is asking and how to generate an output, but must also store and precisely recall from a huge amount of information to do well.While small models can do few-shot learning when world knowledge isn't needed, so far only very large models have shown good results on knowledge-intensive tasks like question answering & fact checking. Atlas as a retrieval-augmented model can often outperform such models.We find that Atlas outperforms much larger non-augmented models on few-shot question answering (NaturalQuestions and TriviaQA) and fact checking (FEVER), and is competitive with various very large models on a wide array of real-world exams (MMLU).Atlas has other benefits too. Retrieved passages can be inspected for better interpretability, and the corpus that Atlas retrieves from can be edited, or even completely swapped out, which enables Atlas to be kept up-to-date without needing to be retrained.Lastly, we also show that Atlas is very strong in traditional full training set settings, setting new states of the art on NQ by 8%, and TriviaQA by 9% and on 5 KILT tasks. Read our paper here: https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03299

Summary: In our recent AMA about No Language Left Behind, our researchers were asked, what is the procedure to extend NLLB-200 to a new language? Do you have any experiments on incorporating a new low-resource language onto the final NLLB-200?: Typically, we extend NLLB-200 to new language pairs rather than a single new language. We finetune the model after gathering seed training data and a reliable test dataset of sentences translated for the new language pairs, if available.If we need more accuracy, we’ll try sourcing better quality seed bitext training data using human annotators or existing translated texts. Alternatively, if we can source sufficient monolingual data in the new target language(s), we’d use data augmentation techniques such as back-translation or additional self-training using the mBART denoising autoencoder objective to get an even better fine-tuned NLLB-200 model for the new language pair(s).Lastly, we check for domain mismatches between the general domain covered by our training data and verify that it is not highly different from our test dataset.If you’re interested in learning more, we’ll be sharing more top Q&A’s. Summary: Existing AI models do a good job of understanding images but require more work to understand the acoustics of environments in the related image.This is why researchers from Meta AI and the University of Texas at Austin are open-sourcing three new models for audio-visual understanding of human speech and sounds in video, helping us achieve immersive AR and VR experiences much more quickly. Using multimodal AI models that can take audio, video, and text signals at one time, AI will be able to deliver sound quality that realistically matches the settings people are immersed in.  The three audio-visual tasks are: 1. Visual Acoustic Matching model — a self-supervised model called AViTAR, which adjusts audio to match the target environment. 2. Visually-Informed Dereverberation of Audio — an end-to-end approach called VIDA, which removes reverberation based on both the observed sounds and the visual scene.3. VisualVoice — a model that uses visual and auditory cues from unlabeled videos to achieve audio-visual speech separation.Learn more about this state-of-the-art work here https://bit.ly/3bqvfCH.

Summary: Few-Shot Learner is a large-scale, multimodal, multilingual, zero or few-shot model to help us better detect harmful content. name: Meta AI
Summary: For the first time, a single multilingual model has outperformed the best bilingual models across 10 out of 14 language pairs to win WMT, a prestigious machine translation competition. Our open source multilingual model provided the best translations for both low-and high-resource languages, showing that the multilingual approach is the future of MT.Not only is it simpler and more scalable, but it also can deliver better translations for everyone. This approach of one-model-for-many-languages also simplifies the development of translation systems in real-world applications — replacing thousands of models with just one will make it easier to bring new applications and services for everyone around the world.Learn more: https://ai.facebook.com/.../the-first-ever-multilingual...

name: Meta AI
Summary: Addressing content that violates our Community Standards & Guidelines is a top priority. name: Meta AI
Summary: Leveraging advances in machine learning and magnetic sensing, ReSkin is an easy-to-replace tactile-sensing skin capable of sharing data between sensors and systems. name: Meta AI
Summary: How can we build AI that learns through touch, like humans do? Through a touch-sensing ecosystem comprising hardware, touch processing, simulators, data sets, and benchmarks. This ecosystem will help to advance the emerging field of touch sensing, and will help us get closer to developing gentler, safer robots capable of understanding the world through touch. We have been developing and open-sourcing parts of this ecosystem. This week, we announced that GelSight will be manufacturing DIGIT, a high-resolution, compact tactile sensor designed for robotic in-hand manipulation. Learn more: https://ai.facebook.com/.../teaching-robots-to-perceive...

name: Meta AI
Summary: Today, as part of a larger tactile-sensing ecosystem, we’re announcing two major advances: DIGIT, a commercially available touch sensing hardware produced by GelSight, and ReSkin, a replaceable, low-cost tactile skin. In addition to commercially available hardware, developing touch sensing as a modality requires an ecosystem of touch processors, simulators, and benchmarks and data sets. Read more about our ongoing work in developing & open-sourcing this ecosystem: https://ai.facebook.com/.../teaching-robots-to-perceive...We’re also open-sourcing ReSkin, a tactile sensor that autocalibrates itself through self-supervision. ReSkin will help advance AI’s ability to obtain and use tactile data, getting us closer to deploying reliable touch sensing in research. Learn more: https://ai.facebook.com/.../reskin-a-versatile...These innovations will advance AI and help us to make progress toward developing gentler, safer robots capable of understanding the world through touch. More accessible touch-sensing hardware could also open up the field of tactile sensing to more researchers.

Summary: Introducing UETorch and PhysNet.UETorch is an open source environment that combines the Torch deep learning environment with the 3D game engine Unreal Engine 4. The Lua/Torch interpreter is embedded directly in the UE4 game and can interact with the UE4 APIs in the game loop: https://github.com/facebook/UETorchPhysNet is an experiment in using deep networks to learn "qualitative physics". A ConvNet is trained to predict whether a tower of wooden blocks will fall or not, and to predict the trajectories of the falling blocks. It is trained with synthetic videos generated with the UETorch environment. Test results are also provided on real images and compared with human performance. PhysNet is described in this arXiv paper: http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.01312At FAIR, we are interested in building AI systems that can perceive, reason, plan, and act in realistic environments. We are also interested in training AI systems to understand how the world works through unsupervised learning. While achieving this in the real world is our ultimate goal, using virtual 3D environments with realistic physical simulation is a great way to experiment. That's why we have built UETorch.We are releasing UETorch in open source so that other research groups can contribute to getting machines to understand the physical world.The PhysNet work is merely the first example of what can be done with UETorch, and the first in a series of works on training AI agents to perceive, reason, plan, act, and generally understand how the physical world works.UETorch and PhysNet are brought to you by FAIR members Adam Lerer, Sam Gross and Rob Fergus.
